instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message: This board has .85V on cpu vcore but no output through internal screen or external monitor. No spill. Not sure where to go next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message:
Do you get voltage on all coils?
Check for USB activity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message: No USB activity. I'll check coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message: No USB activity. No <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>. .535 in diode mode on that line.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message: I replaced <CHIP>U8230</CHIP>. Has <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> now, but still not turning on. It does have the <DIODE>D6900</DIODE> <SIGNAL>SYS_DETECT_LED</SIGNAL> now though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message:
Apart of checking all coils voltage, see if you get the ones from pages 49/50 too.
Try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message:
Ok, I've checked everything. The only thing I can find missing is <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5SW</SIGNAL> at 0V (<SIGNAL>P1V2S5SW_HSMUX_EN</SIGNAL> is at 0V)

How do you start this in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message:
Check resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>P1V2S5SW_HSMUX_EN</SIGNAL>.
Was the machine used with fake charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>P1V2S5SW_HSMUX_EN</SIGNAL>: 2.8M Ohms .795 in diode mode.

The charger that's with it is real. Not sure if they used a different one at some point though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message: I'm about to let this one go. Any last ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message:
"How do you start this in SMC bypass mode?"
Press power button, connect charger and maintain pressing 5-10s.
I suppose to be the same procedure like old models, try it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message: SMC bypass didn't change anything. Comparing it to a good board, every voltage I can possibly check is there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5SW</SIGNAL> at 0V"
Is the same on the working board too?

You can try new BIOS, just in case...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has CPU but no video. No liquid-damage.
threads.message: Yes, <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5SW</SIGNAL> is at 0V on a good board. If it's a BIOS issue, I'll just let this go. Can't afford to spend the time on that. Thanks.
